title: Smith v Jones [2024] EWHC 123 (Costs)
summary: This case involves a dispute over costs recovery in a professional negligence claim, focusing on the application of proportionality tests to detailed assessment.
content:
# Smith v Jones [2024] EWHC 123 (Costs)

## Summary
This case involves a dispute over costs recovery in a professional negligence claim.

## Participants
- John Smith (Claimant)
- Alice Jones (Defendant)
- Johnson & Partners LLP (Solicitors for the Claimant)
- Master Brown (Costs Judge)

## Key Issues
- Whether the proportionality test applies to individual items or the total bill
- The relevance of complexity in pre-trial settlements
- Application of the new proportionality test under CPR

## Highlights
> "The court held that the proportionality test must be applied to the total costs being assessed, and not separately to each item of cost."

> "Where a claim settles before trial, the complexity of the matter is still relevant to the assessment of proportionality."

## Outcome
The court allowed 70% of the claimed costs, finding that while some elements appeared disproportionate in isolation, the overall bill was proportionate given the complexity and importance of the matter.
author: William Mackenzie

title: Brown v NHS Trust [2024] EWHC 234 (QB)
summary: A landmark decision on costs budgeting in clinical negligence claims, establishing new guidelines for the application of Precedent H.
content:
# Brown v NHS Trust [2024] EWHC 234 (QB)

## Summary
This judgment sets new precedent for costs budgeting in clinical negligence claims.

## Participants
- Margaret Brown (Claimant)
- Central NHS Trust (Defendant)
- Justice Williams
- Ms. Sarah Thompson QC (for the Claimant)
- Mr. Robert Jackson QC (for the Defendant)

## Background
The claimant suffered serious injuries during surgery and brought a claim against the NHS Trust. At the costs management conference, there was significant dispute about the appropriate level of costs for expert evidence and trial preparation.

## Highlights
> "The purpose of costs budgeting is not to reduce costs to their minimum possible level, but to ensure they are reasonable, proportionate and necessary."

> "In complex clinical negligence matters where causation is in dispute, a more generous approach to expert fees may be justified."

## Key Principles
1. Proportionality must be judged against the specific circumstances of the case
2. The complexity of expert evidence may justify higher costs
3. Efficiency in litigation process should be considered

## Outcome
The court approved a costs budget with modifications, allowing most of the expert fees but reducing the trial preparation contingency by 25%.
author: William Mackenzie

title: Wilson & Co v Thompson [2024] EWHC 345 (Costs)
summary: A solicitor-client dispute regarding a conditional fee agreement and success fees in a commercial litigation case.
content:
# Wilson & Co v Thompson [2024] EWHC 345 (Costs)

## Summary
This case addresses the enforceability of a conditional fee agreement (CFA) and the reasonableness of success fees in commercial litigation.

## Participants
- Wilson & Co Solicitors (Claimant)
- James Thompson (Defendant/Former Client)
- Deputy Costs Judge Mitchell

## Key Issues
- Whether the CFA was compliant with regulations
- The adequacy of risk assessment for the success fee
- Whether information provided to the client was sufficient

## Legal Background
The Defendant had instructed the Claimant in commercial litigation under a CFA with a 100% success fee. After successful resolution, the Defendant challenged the enforceability of the CFA and the reasonableness of the success fee.

## Highlights
> "A solicitor must provide sufficient information to enable the client to make an informed decision about the funding arrangement. This requires more than mechanical recitation of terms."

> "The level of success fee must be justified by a proper assessment of risk at the time the CFA was entered into, not by reference to hindsight."

## Outcome
The court found the CFA to be enforceable but reduced the success fee from 100% to 50%, finding that the initial risk assessment had not justified the higher percentage.
author: William Mackenzie
